verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:1
verses.text: second instruction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:2
verses.text: To those about to be illuminated; and concerning women who adorn themselves with plaiting of hair, and gold, and concerning those who have used omens, and amulets, and incantations, all which are foreign to Christianity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:3
verses.text: I have come to ask first of all for some fruit in return for the words lately said out of brotherly love to you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:4
verses.text: For we do not speak in order that ye should hear simply, but in order that ye should remember what has been said, and may afford us evidence of this, by your works.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:5
verses.text: Yea, rather, not us, but, God, who knows the secrets of the heart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:6
verses.text: On this account indeed instruction is so called, in order that even when we are absent, our discourse may instruct your hearts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:7
verses.text: And be not surprised if, after an interval of ten days only, we have come asking for fruit from the seed sown.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:8
verses.text: For in one day it is possible at once to let the seed fall, and to accomplish the harvest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:9
verses.text: For strengthened not by our own power alone, but by the influence which comes from God, we are summoned to the conflict.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:10
verses.text: Let as many therefore as have received what has been spoken, and have fulfilled it by their works, remain reaching forth to the things which are before.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:11
verses.text: But let as many as have not yet arrived at this good achievement, arrive at it straightway, that they may dispel the condemnation which arises out of their sloth by their diligence for the future.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:12
verses.text: For it is possible, it is indeed possible for him who has been very slothful, by using diligence for the future to recover the whole loss of the time that is past.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:13
verses.text: Wherefore, He says, "To-day if ye will hear his voice, harden not your hearts, as in the day of provocation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:14
verses.text: And this, He says, exhorting and counselling us; that we should never despair, but so long as we are here, should have good hopes, and should lay hold on what is before us, and hasten towards the prize of our high calling of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:15
verses.text: This then let us do, and let us inquire into the names of this great gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:16
verses.text: For as ignorance of the greatness of this dignity makes those who are honored with it more slothful, so when it is known it renders them thankful, and makes them more earnest; and anyhow it would be disgraceful and ridiculous that they who enjoy such glory and honors from God, should not even know what the names of it are intended to show forth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:17
verses.text: And why do I speak about this gift, for if thou wilt consider the common name of our race, thou wilt receive the greatest instruction and incentive to virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:18
verses.text: For this name "Man," we do not define according as they who are without define it, but as the Divine Scripture has bidden us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:19
verses.text: For a man is not merely whosoever has hands and feet of a man, nor whosoever is rational only, but whosoever practices piety and virtue with boldness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:20
verses.text: Hear, at least, what he says concerning Job.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:21
verses.text: For in saying that "there was a man in the land of Ausis," he does not describe him in those terms in which they who are without describe him, nor does he say this because he had two feet and broad nails, but he added the evidences of his piety and said, "just, true, fearing God, eschewing every evil deed," showing that this is a man; even as therefore another says, "Fear God, and keep his commandments, because this is the whole man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:22
verses.text: But if the name man affords such a great incentive to virtue, much rather the term faithful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:23
verses.text: For thou art called faithful on this account, because thou hast faith in God, and thyself art entrusted from Him with righteousness, sanctification, cleansing of soul, adoption, the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:24
verses.text: He entrusted thee with these, and handed them over to thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:25
verses.text: Thou in turn hast entrusted, and handed over other things to him, almsgiving, prayers, self-control and every other virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:26
verses.text: And why do I say almsgiving? If thou givest him even a cup of cold water, thou shalt not indeed lose this, but even this he keeps with care against that day, and will restore it with overflowing abundance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:27
verses.text: For this truly is wonderful, that he does not keep only that which has been entrusted to him, but in recompensing it increases it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:28
verses.text: This too he has bidden thee do according to thy power, with what has been entrusted to thee, to extend the holiness which thou hast received, and to make the righteousness which comes from the laver brighter, and the gift of grace more radiant; even as therefore Paul did, increasing all the good things which he received by his subsequent labors, and his zeal, and his diligence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:29
verses.text: And look at the carefulness of God; neither did he give the whole to thee then, nor withhold the whole, but gave part, and promised part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:30
verses.text: And for what reason did he not give the whole then? In order that thou mightest show thy faith about Him, believing, on his promise alone, in what was not yet given.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:31
verses.text: And for what reason again did he not there dispense the whole, but did give the grace of the Spirit, and righteousness and sanctification? In order that he might lighten thy labors for thee, and by what has been already given may also put thee in good hope for that which is to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:32
verses.text: On this account, too, thou art about to be called newly-enlightened, because thy light is ever new, if thou wilt, and is never quenched.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:33
verses.text: For this light of day, whether we will or no, the night succeeds, but darkness knows not that light's ray.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:34
verses.text: "For the light shineth in the darkness, and the darkness apprehended it not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:35
verses.text: Not so bright at least is the world, when the sunbeams come forth, as the soul shines and becomes brighter when it has received grace from the Spirit and learns more exactly the nature of the case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:36
verses.text: For when night prevails, and there is darkness, often a man has seen a coil of rope and has thought it was a serpent, and has fled from an approaching friend as from an enemy, and being aware of some noise, has become very much alarmed; but when the day has come, nothing of this sort could happen, but all appears just as it really is; which thing also occurs in the case of our soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:37
verses.text: For when grace has come, and driven away the darkness of the understanding, we learn the exact nature of things, and what was before dreadful to us becomes contemptible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:38
verses.text: For we no longer fear death, after learning exactly, from this sacred initiation, that death is not death, but a sleep and a seasonable slumber; nor poverty nor disease, nor any other such thing, knowing that we are on our way to a better life, undefiled and incorruptible, and free from all such vicissitudes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:39
verses.text: Let us not therefore remain craving after the things of this life, neither after the luxury of the table, or costliness of raiment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:40
verses.text: For thou hast the most excellent of raiment, thou hast a spiritual table thou hast the glory from on high, and Christ is become to thee all things, thy table, thy raiment, thy home, thy head, thy stem.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:41
verses.text: "For as many of you as were baptized into Christ, did put on Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:42
verses.text: See how he has become raiment for thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:43
verses.text: Dost thou wish to learn how he becomes a table for thee? "He who eateth me," says He, "as I live because of the Father, he also shall live because of me;" and that he becometh a home for thee, "he that eateth my flesh abideth in me, and I in him;" and that He is stem He says again, "I am the vine, ye the branches," and that he is brother, and friend, and bride-groom, "I no longer call you servants: for ye are my friends;" and Paul again, "I espoused you to one husband, that I might present you as a pure virgin to Christ;" and again, "That he might be the first-born among many brethren;" and we become not his brethren only, but also his children, "For behold," he says, "I and the children which God has given me" and not this only, but His members, and His body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:44
verses.text: For as if what has been said were not enough to show forth the love and the good will which He has shown forth towards us, He has added another thing greater and nearer still, calling himself besides, our head.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:45
verses.text: Knowing all these matters, beloved, requite thy benefactor by the best conversation, and considering the greatness of the sacrifice, adorn the members of thy body; consider what thou receivest in thine hand, and never suffer it to strike any one, nor shame what has been honored with so great a gift by the sin of a blow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:46
verses.text: Consider what thou receivest in thine hand, and keep it clean from all covetousness and extortion; think that thou dost not receive this in thy hand, but also puttest it to thy mouth, and guard thy tongue in purity from base and insolent words, blasphemy, perjury, and all other such things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:47
verses.text: For it is disastrous that what is ministered to by such most dread mysteries, and has been dyed red with such blood, and has become a golden sword, should be perverted to purposes of raillery, and insult, and buffoonery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:48
verses.text: Reverence the honor with which God has honoured it, and bring it not down to the vileness of sin, but having reflected again that after the hand and the tongue, the heart receives this dread mystery, do not ever weave a plot against thy neighbor, but keep thy thoughts pure from all evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:49
verses.text: Thus thou shalt be able to keep thine eyes too, and thy hearing safe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:50
verses.text: For is it not monstrous, after this mystic voice is borne from heaven—I mean the voice of the Cherubim—to defile thy hearing with lewd songs, and dissolute melodies? and does it not deserve the utmost punishment if, with the same eyes with which thou lookest upon the unspeakable and dread mysteries, thou lookest upon harlots, and dost commit adultery in thy heart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:51
verses.text: Thou art called to a marriage, beloved: enter not in clad in sordid raiment, but take a robe suitable to the marriage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:52
verses.text: For if when men are called to a material marriage, though they be poorer than all others, they often possess themselves of or buy clean raiment, and so go to meet those who called them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:53
verses.text: Do thou too who hast been called to a spiritual marriage, and to a royal banquet, consider what kind of raiment it would be right for thee to buy, but rather there is not even need to purchase, yea he himself who calls thee gives it thee gratis, in order that thou mayest not be able to plead poverty in excuse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:54
verses.text: Keep, therefore, the raiment which thou receivedst.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:55
verses.text: For if thou losest it, thou wilt not be able to use it henceforth, or to buy it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:56
verses.text: For this kind of raiment is nowhere sold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:57
verses.text: Hast thou heard how those who were initiated, in old time, groaned, and beat their breasts, their conscience thereupon exciting them? Beware then, beloved, that thou do not at any time suffer like this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:58
verses.text: But how wilt thou not suffer, if thou dost not cast off the wicked habit of evil men? For this reason I said before, and speak now and will not cease speaking, if any has not rectified the defects in his morals, nor furnished himself with easily acquired virtue, let him not be baptized.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:59
verses.text: For the laver is able to remit former sins, but there is no little fear, and no ordinary danger lest we return to them, and our remedy become a wound.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:60
verses.text: For by how much greater the grace is, by so much is the punishment more for those who sin after these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:61
verses.text: In order, therefore, that we return not to our former vomit, let us henceforward discipline ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:62
verses.text: For that we must repent beforehand, and desist from our former evil, and so come forward for grace, hear what John says, and what the leader of the apostles says to those who are about to be baptized.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:63
verses.text: For the one says, "Bring forth fruit worthy of repentance, and begin not to say within yourselves, we have Abraham to our Father;" and the other says again to those who question him, "Repent ye and be baptized every one of you in the name of the Lord Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:64
verses.text: Now he who repents, no longer touches the same matters of which he repented.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:65
verses.text: On this account, also, we are bidden to say, "I renounce thee, Satan," in order that we may never more return to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:66
verses.text: As therefore happens in the case of painters from life, so let it happen in your case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:67
verses.text: For they, arranging their boards, and tracing white lines upon them, and sketching the royal likeness in outline, before they apply the actual colors, rub out some lines, and change some for others, rectifying mistakes, and altering what is amiss with all freedom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:68
verses.text: But when they put on the coloring for good, it is no longer in their power to rub out again, and to change one thing for another, since they injure the beauty of the portrait, and the result becomes an eyesore.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:69
verses.text: Consider that thy soul is the portrait; before therefore the true coloring of the spirit comes, wipe out habits which have wrongly been implanted in thee, whether swearing, or falsehood, or insolence, or base talking, or jesting, or whatever else thou hast a habit of doing of things unlawful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:70
verses.text: Away with the habit, in order that thou mayest not return to it, after baptism.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:71
verses.text: The laver causes the sins to disappear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:72
verses.text: Correct thy habits, so that when the colors are applied, and the royal likeness is brought out, thou mayest no more wipe them out in the future; and add damage and scars to the beauty which has been given thee by God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:73
verses.text: Restrain therefore anger, extinguish passion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:74
verses.text: Be not thou vexed, be sympathizing, be not exasperated, nor say, "I have been injured in regard to my soul".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:75
verses.text: No one is injured in regard to the soul if we do not injure ourselves in regard to the soul; and how this is, I now say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:76
verses.text: Has any one taken away thy substance? He has not injured thee in regard to thy soul, but thy money.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:77
verses.text: But if thou cherish ill-will against him, thou hast injured thyself in regard to thy soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:78
verses.text: For the money taken away has wrought thee no damage, nay has even been profitable, but thou by not dismissing thine anger wilt give account in the other world for this cherishing of ill-will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:79
verses.text: Has any one reviled thee and insulted thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:80
verses.text: He has in no way injured thy soul, and not even thy body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:81
verses.text: Hast thou reviled in return and insulted? Thou hast injured thyself in regard to thy soul, for for the words which thou hast said thou art about to render account there; and this I wish you to know chiefly of all, that the Christian, and faithful man, no one is able to injure in regard to the soul, not even the devil himself; and not only is this wonderful, that God hath made us inaccessible to all his designs, but that he has constituted us fit for the practice of virtue, and there is no hinderance, if we will, even though we be poor, weak in body, outcast, nameless, bondservants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:82
verses.text: For neither poverty, nor infirmity, nor deformity of body, nor servitude, nor any other of such things could ever become a hinderance to virtue; and why do I say, poor, and a bondservant, and nameless? Even if thou art a prisoner, not even this would be ever any hinderance to thee as regards virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:83
verses.text: And how this is I proceed to say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:84
verses.text: Has any of thy household grieved thee and provoked thee? dismiss thy wrath against him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:85
verses.text: Have bonds, and poverty, and obscurity been any hinderance to thee in this respect? and why do I say hinderance? They have both helped and contributed to restrain pride.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:86
verses.text: Hast thou seen another prospering? do not envy him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:87
verses.text: For not even in this case is poverty a bar.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:88
verses.text: Again, whenever thou needest to pray, do so with a sober and watchful mind, and nothing shall be a bar even in that case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:89
verses.text: Show all meekness, forbearance, self-restraint, gravity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:90
verses.text: For these things need no external helps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:91
verses.text: And this especially is the chief point about virtue, that it has no necessity for wealth, power, glory, nor anything of that kind, but of a sanctified soul alone, and it seeks for nothing more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:92
verses.text: And behold, also, the same thing happening in respect of grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:93
verses.text: For if any one be lame, if he has had his eyes put out, if he be maimed in body, if he has fallen into the last extremity of weakness, grace is not hindered from coming by any of these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:94
verses.text: For it only seeks a soul receiving it with readiness, and all these external things it passes over.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:95
verses.text: For in the case of worldly soldiers, those who are about to enlist them for the army seek for stature of body and healthy condition, and it is not only necessary that he who is about to become a soldier should have these alone, but he must also be free.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:96
verses.text: For if anybody be a slave, he is rejected.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:97
verses.text: But the King of Heaven seeks for nothing of this kind, but receives slaves into his army, and aged people, and the languid in limb, and is not ashamed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:98
verses.text: What is more merciful than this? What could be more kind? For he seeks for what is in our own power, but they seek for what is not in our power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:99
verses.text: For to be a slave or free is not our doing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:100
verses.text: To be tall, again, or short is not in our own power, or to be aged, or well grown, and such like.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:101
verses.text: But to be forbearing and kind, and so forth, are matters of our own choice; and God demands of us only those things of which we have control.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:102
verses.text: And quite reasonably.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:103
verses.text: For He does not call us to grace because of his own need, but because of doing us kindness; but kings, because of services required by them; and they carry men off to an outward and material warfare, but He to a spiritual combat; and it is not only in the case of heathen wars, but in the case of the games also that one may see the same analogy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:104
verses.text: For they who are about to be brought into the theatre, do not descend to the contest until the herald himself takes them beneath the gaze of all, and leads them round, shouting out and saying, "Has any one a charge against this person?" although in that case the struggle is not concerned with the soul, but with the body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:105
verses.text: Wherefore then dost thou demand proofs of nobleness? But in this case there is nothing of the kind, but all is different, our contest not consisting of hand locked in hand, but in philosophy of soul, and excellence of mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:106
verses.text: The president of our conflicts does the opposite.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:107
verses.text: For he does not take us, and lead us round and say, "Has any one a charge against this man?" but cries out, "Though all men, though demons, stand up with the devil and accuse him of extreme and unspeakable crimes, I reject him not, nor abhor him, but removing him from his accusers, and freeing him from his wickedness, thus I bring him to the contest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:108
verses.text: And this is very reasonable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:109
verses.text: For there indeed the president contributes nothing towards the victory, in the case of the combatants, but stands still in the midst.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:110
verses.text: But here, the President of the contests for holiness becomes a fellow-combatant, and helper, sharing with them the conflict against the devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:111
verses.text: And not only is this the wonderful thing that he remits our sins, but that he not even reveals them nor makes them manifest and patent, nor compels us to come forward into the midst, and to tell out our errors, but bids us make our defense to him alone, and to confess ourselves to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:112
verses.text: And yet among secular judges, if any tell any of the robbers or grave-riflers, when they are arrested, to tell their errors and be quit of their punishment, they would accede to this with all readiness, despising the shame through desire of safety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:113
verses.text: But in this case there is nothing of this kind, but he both remits the sins, nor compels us to marshal them in array before any spectators.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:114
verses.text: But one thing alone he seeks, that he who enjoys this remission should learn the greatness of the gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:115
verses.text: How is it not, therefore, absurd that in case where he does us service, he should be content with our testimony only, but in those where we serve him we seek for others as witnesses, and do a thing for ostentation's sake? While we wonder then at his kindliness, let us show forth our doings, and before all others let us curb the vehemence of our tongue, and not always be giving utterance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:116
verses.text: "For in the multitude of words there wanteth not transgression".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:117
verses.text: If indeed then thou hast anything useful to say, open thy lips.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:118
verses.text: But if there be nothing necessary for thee to say, be silent, for it is better.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:119
verses.text: Art thou a handicraftsman? as thou sittest at work, sing psalms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:120
verses.text: Dost thou not wish to sing with thy mouth? do this in thine heart; a psalm is a great companion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:121
verses.text: In this case thou shalt undergo nothing serious, but shalt be able to sit in thy workshop as in a monastery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:122
verses.text: For not suitableness of place, but strictness of morals will afford us quiet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:123
verses.text: Paul, at least, pursuing his trade in a workshop suffered no injury to his own virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:124
verses.text: Do not thou therefore say, How can I, being a handicraftsman and a poor man, be a philosopher? This is indeed the very reason why thou mayest be a philosopher.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:125
verses.text: For poverty is far more conducive to piety for us than wealth, and work than idleness; since wealth is even a hinderance to those who do not take heed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:126
verses.text: For when it is needful to dismiss anger, to extinguish envy, to curb passion, to offer prayer, to exhibit forbearance and meekness, kindliness and charity, when would poverty be a bar? For it is not possible by spending money to accomplish these things, but by exhibiting a right disposition; almsgiving especially needs money, but even it shines forth in greater degree through poverty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:127
verses.text: For she who spent the two mites was poorer than all men, and yet surpassed all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:128
verses.text: Let us not then consider wealth to be anything great, nor gold to be better than clay.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:129
verses.text: For the value of material things is not owing to their nature, but to our estimate of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:130
verses.text: For if any one would inquire carefully, iron is much more necessary than gold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:131
verses.text: For the one contributes to no need of our life, but the other has furnished us with the greater part of our needs, ministering to countless arts; and why do I speak of a comparison between gold and iron? For these stones are more necessary than precious stones.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:132
verses.text: For of those nothing serviceable could be made, but out of these, houses and walls and cities are erected.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:133
verses.text: But do thou show me what gain could be derived from these pearls, rather what harm would not happen? For in order that thou mayest wear one pearl drop, countless poor people are pinched with hunger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:134
verses.text: What excuse wilt thou hit upon? what pardon?  Dost thou wish to adorn thy face? Do so not with pearls, but with modesty, and dignity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:135
verses.text: So thy countenance will be more full of grace in the eyes of thy husband.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:136
verses.text: For the other kind of adorning is wont to plunge him into a suspicion of jealousy, and into enmity, quarrelsomeness and strife, for nothing is more annoying than a face which is suspected.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:137
verses.text: But the ornament of compassion and modesty casts out all evil suspicion, and will draw thy partner to thee more strongly than any bond.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:138
verses.text: For natural beauty does not impart such comeliness to the face as does the disposition of him who beholds it, and nothing is so wont to produce that disposition as modesty and dignity; so that if any woman be comely, and her husband be ill affected towards her, she appears to him the most worthless of all women; and if she do not happen to be fair of face, but her husband be well affected towards her, she appears more comely than all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:139
verses.text: For sentence is given not according to the nature of what is beheld, but according to the disposition of the beholders.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:140
verses.text: Adorn thy face then with modesty, dignity, pity, lovingkindness, charity, affection for thy husband, forbearance, meekness, endurance of ill.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:141
verses.text: These are the tints of virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:142
verses.text: By means of these thou wilt attract angels not human beings to be thy lovers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:143
verses.text: By means of these thou hast God to commend thee, and when God receives thee, he will certainly win over thy husband for thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:144
verses.text: For if the wisdom of a man illuminates his countenance, much more does the virtue of a woman illuminate her face; and if thou considerest this to be a great ornament, tell me what will be the advantage of the pearls in that day? But why is it necessary to speak of that day, since it is possible to show all this from what happens now.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:145
verses.text: When, then, they who thought fit to revile the emperor were dragged to the judgment hall, and were in danger of extreme measures being taken, then the mothers, and the wives, laying aside their necklaces, and their golden ornaments, and pearls, and all adornment, and golden raiment, wearing a simple and mean dress, and besprinkled with ashes, prostrated themselves before the doors of the judgment hall and thus won over the judges; and if in the case of these earthly courts of justice, the golden ornaments, and the pearls, and the variegated dress would have been a snare and a betrayal, but forbearance, and meekness, and ashes, and tears, and mean garments persuaded the judge, much more would this take place in the case of that impartial and dread tribunal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:146
verses.text: For what reason wilt thou be able to state, what defense, when the Master lays these pearls to thy charge, and brings the poor who have perished with hunger into the midst? On this account Paul said, "not with braided hair, or gold, or pearls, or costly raiment".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:147
verses.text: For therein would be a snare.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:148
verses.text: And if we were to enjoy them continually, yet we shall lay them aside with death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:149
verses.text: But arising out of virtue there is all security, and no vicissitude and changeableness, but here it makes us more secure, and also accompanies us there.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:150
verses.text: Dost thou wish to possess pearls, and never to lay aside this wealth? Take off all ornament and place it in the hands of Christ through the poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:151
verses.text: He will keep all thy wealth for thee, when He shall raise up thy body with much radiancy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:152
verses.text: Then He shall invest thee with better wealth and greater ornament, since this present is mean and absurd.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:153
verses.text: Consider then whom thou wishest to please, and for whose sake thou puttest on this ornament, not in order that the ropemaker and the coppersmith and the huckster may admire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:154
verses.text: Then art thou not ashamed, nor blushest thou when thou showest thyself to them? doing all on their account whom thou dost not consider worthy of accosting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:155
verses.text: How then wilt thou laugh this fancy to scorn? If thou wilt remember that word, which thou sentest forth when thou wert initiated, I renounce thee, Satan, and thy pomp, and thy service.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:156
verses.text: For the frenzy about pearls is a pomp of Satan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:157
verses.text: For thou didst receive gold not in order that thou mightest bind it on to thy body, but in order that thou mightest release and nourish the poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:158
verses.text: Say therefore constantly, I renounce thee, Satan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:159
verses.text: Nothing is more safe than this word if we shall prove it by our deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:160
verses.text: This I think it right that you who are about to be initiated should learn.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:161
verses.text: For this word is a covenant with the Master.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:162
verses.text: And just as we, when we buy slaves, first ask those who are being sold if they are willing to be our servants: So also does Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:163
verses.text: When He is about to receive thee into service, He first asks if thou wishest to leave that cruel and relentless tyrant, and He receives covenants from thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:164
verses.text: For his service is not forced upon thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:165
verses.text: And see the lovingkindness of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:166
verses.text: For we, before we put down the price, ask those who are being sold, and when we have learned that they are willing, then we put down the price.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:167
verses.text: But Christ not so, but He even put down the price for us all; his precious blood.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:168
verses.text: For, He says, ye were bought with a price.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:169
verses.text: Notwithstanding, not even then does He compel those who are unwilling, to serve him; but except thou hast grace, He says, and of thine own accord and will determinest to enroll thyself under my rule, I do not compel, nor force thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:170
verses.text: And we should not have chosen to buy wicked slaves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:171
verses.text: But if we should at any time have so chosen, we buy them with a perverted choice, and put down a corresponding price for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:172
verses.text: But Christ, buying ungrateful and lawless slaves, put down the price of a servant of first quality, nay rather much more, and so much greater that neither speech nor thought can set forth its greatness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:173
verses.text: For neither giving heaven, nor earth, nor sea, but giving up that which is more valuable than all these, his own blood, thus He bought us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:174
verses.text: And after all these things, he does not require of us witnesses, or registration, but is content with the single word, if thou sayest it from thy heart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:175
verses.text: "I renounce thee, Satan, and thy pomp," has included all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:176
verses.text: Let us then say this, "I renounce thee, Satan," as men who are about in that world at that day to have that word demanded of them, and let us keep it in order that we may then return this deposit safe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:177
verses.text: But Satan's pomps are theatres, and the circus, and all sin, and observance of days, and incantations and omens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:178
verses.text: "And what are omens?" says one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:179
verses.text: Often when going forth from his own house he has seen a one-eyed or lame man, and has shunned him as an omen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:180
verses.text: This is a pomp of Satan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:181
verses.text: For meeting the man does not make the day turn out ill, but to live in sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:182
verses.text: When thou goest forth, then, beware of one thing—that sin does not meet thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:183
verses.text: For this it is which trips us up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:184
verses.text: And without this the devil will be able to do us no harm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:185
verses.text: What sayest thou? Thou seest a man, and shunnest him as an omen, and dost not see the snare of the devil, how he sets thee at war with him who has done thee no wrong, how he makes thee the enemy of thy brother on no just pretext; but God has bidden us love our enemies; but thou art turned away from him who did thee no wrong, having nothing to charge him with, and dost thou not consider how great is the absurdity, how great the shame, rather how great is the danger? Can I speak of anything more absurd? I am ashamed, indeed, and I blush: But for your salvation's sake, I am, I am compelled to speak of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:186
verses.text: If a virgin meet him he says the day becomes unsuccessful; but if a harlot meet him, it is propitious, and profitable, and full of much business; are you ashamed? and do you smite your foreheads, and bend to the ground? But do not this on account of the words which I have spoken, but of the deeds which have been done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:187
verses.text: See then, in this case, how the devil hid his snare, in order that we might turn away from the modest, but salute and be friendly to the unchaste.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:188
verses.text: For since he has heard Christ saying that "He who looketh on a woman to desire her, has already committed adultery with her," and has seen many get the better of unchastity, wishing by another wrong to cast them again into sin, by this superstitious observance he gladly persuades them to pay attention to whorish women.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:189
verses.text: And what is one to say about them who use charms and amulets, and encircle their heads and feet with golden coins of Alexander of Macedon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:190
verses.text: Are these our hopes, tell me, that after the cross and death of our Master, we should place our hopes of salvation on an image of a Greek king? Dost thou not know what great result the cross has achieved? It has abolished death, has extinguished sin, has made Hades useless, has undone the power of the devil, and is it not worth trusting for the health of the body? It has raised up the whole world, and dost thou not take courage in it? And what wouldest thou be worthy to suffer, tell me? Thou dost not only have amulets always with thee, but incantations bringing drunken and half-witted old women into thine house, and art thou not ashamed, and dost thou not blush, after so great philosophy, to be terrified at such things? and there is a graver thing than this error.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:191
verses.text: For when we deliver these exhortations, and lead them away, thinking that they defend themselves, they say, that the woman is a Christian who makes these incantations, and utters nothing else than the name of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:192
verses.text: On this account I especially hate and turn away from her, because she makes use of the name of God, with a view to ribaldry.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:193
verses.text: For even the demons uttered the name of God, but still they were demons, and thus they used to say to Christ, "We know thee who thou art, the Holy One of God," and notwithstanding, he rebuked them, and drave them away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:194
verses.text: On this account, then, I beseech you to cleanse yourselves from this error, and to keep hold of this word as a staff; and just as without sandals, and cloak, no one of you would choose to go down to the market-place, so without this word never enter the market-place, but when thou art about to pass over the threshold of the gateway, say this word first: I leave thy ranks, Satan, and thy pomp, and thy service, and I join the ranks of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:195
verses.text: And never go forth without this word.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:196
verses.text: This shall be a staff to thee, this thine armor, this an impregnable fortress, and accompany this word with the sign of the cross on thy forehead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Instructions to Catechumens II 1:197
verses.text: For thus not only a man who meets you, but even the devil himself, will be unable to hurt you at all, when he sees thee everywhere appearing with these weapons; and discipline thyself by these means henceforth, in order that when thou receivest the seal thou mayest be a well-equipped soldier, and planting thy trophy against the devil, may receive the crown of righteousness, which may it be the lot of us all to obtain, through the grace and lovingkindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, with whom be glory to the Father and to the Holy Spirit for ever and ever—Amen.
